questions.question: I would be surprised if he ........................
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had known, I ......................... you straightaway.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Rarely ................................ such a good film.
questions.description: When the sentence begins with expressions like rarely, hardly or only, the auxiliary verb goes before the subject.

questions.question: My father often ........................ a nap in the afternoon.
questions.description: We use the simple present tense to talk about facts, routines and habits.

questions.question: If you don't want to go, you ...........................
questions.description: We use 'need not' to show the lack of obligation.

questions.question: You don't need ........................... on Saturdays.
questions.description: When need is used as an ordinary verb, it is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: You ..................................... on Saturdays.
questions.description: When need is used as a modal auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: If I ............................. you, I would accept this offer.
questions.description: Both 'was' and 'were' are possible here however, 'were' is preferred.

questions.question: You ............................... mend your ways.
questions.description: We use 'had better' to give strong advice.

questions.question: She .............................. that she would come.
questions.description: After 'tell' we use a personal object.

questions.question: I sent ....................... a letter yesterday.
questions.description: 'Sent' is one of those verbs that can be followed by two objects - a direct object and an indirect object. When the indirect object goes first, there is no preposition.

questions.question: I sent flowers ..........................
questions.description: 'Sent' is one of those verbs that can be followed by two objects - a direct object and an indirect object. When the direct object goes first, we use the preposition 'to' or 'for' before the indirect object.
